responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?

extracted_value.Role: Develop, host, and deliver software applications via cloud
extracted_value.Interaction with offering company: Not applicable - this is the offering company
extracted_value.Interaction with other actors: Host software on cloud infrastructure; deliver services to customers; negotiate pricing and contracts with customers; share revenue with content owners and network operators

extracted_value.Role: End users of SaaS applications
extracted_value.Interaction with offering company: Pay subscription fees or purchase licenses; use software via public cloud or internal data center; negotiate agreements and pricing; request customizations and support
extracted_value.Interaction with other actors: May interact with network operators for service delivery (Firm B case)

extracted_value.Role: Infrastructure and delivery channel providers
extracted_value.Interaction with offering company: Operate gaming platforms; deliver services to end users; determine revenue models used; share revenue from subscriptions
extracted_value.Interaction with other actors: Deliver games to players through broadband network; collect payments from consumers

extracted_value.Role: License content to SaaS providers
extracted_value.Interaction with offering company: License game content to Firm B; receive share of revenue (e.g., $2 out of $5)
extracted_value.Interaction with other actors: Provide content that is delivered through network operators to end users

extracted_value.Role: Provide underlying IaaS and PaaS
extracted_value.Interaction with offering company: Provide computation, storage capacity, and platform services for hosting SaaS applications
extracted_value.Interaction with other actors: Enable multi-tenant/multi-instance architectures for SaaS providers

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3-4: 'The network operators operate the platform and deliver games to players' set-top boxes or to PCs through their broadband network... It is based on revenue sharing between three players, the content owner, a portal, and ourselves â€“all sharing the content revenue. If the content is [equivalent to] five dollars, we share it so that there are two dollars for the portal, and two dollars for the content owner, and one for us' | Page 1: 'Cloud computing can be divided roughly into three service layers... (i) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), which provides computation and storage capacity, (ii) Platform as a Service (PaaS), which provides software development tools plus an application execution environment, and (iii) Software as a Service (SaaS), which provides applications on top of PaaS and IaaS'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?

extracted_value.role: Exclusive partners who only work for ERP Co and build their services around ERP Co products; develop customized systems and services for various industries
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Synergistic integration - develop new products and services based on ERP Co system; receive up to 50% of initial license fees; hand-in-hand transition to cloud
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Direct sales to small-medium size business customers; represent ERP Co in local markets

extracted_value.role: Partners who mainly work with ERP Co but also engage with other businesses; provide customization and implementation services
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Co-opetition relationship - addition/exchange type collaboration; redistribute ERP Co products; receive portion of license fees
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Sell to small-medium size business segment; also sell competing products from other vendors

extracted_value.role: Represent ERP Co or their products in micro markets and local markets
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Co-opetition relationship - simple redistribution or basic customization services
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Penetrate micro and local markets; may also work with competing vendors

extracted_value.role: End users who purchase out-of-box standardized products
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Direct purchase from ERP Co; receive online product training and helpdesk support only
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: No intermediary involvement

extracted_value.role: End users requiring tailored systems based on standard ERP Co product; largest customer segment
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Indirect relationship through VAR partners
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Obtain customized systems and services from VAR partners

extracted_value.role: End users requiring intensive consulting services
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Currently not the focus of ERP Co
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Limited detail provided

extracted_value.role: Major supplier and technology provider
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Supplies technology components; co-opetition relationship as Microsoft also sells competing software on global scale
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Competes with ERP Co in enterprise software market

extracted_value.role: Technology infrastructure provider owned by ERP Co
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Internal supplier relationship
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Provides IT infrastructure support

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5, Section 5.1: 'The second segment is small and medium size business with less than 1000 employees, where ERP Co works closely with their partners, all what they refer to as value added resellers. Here, all the sales go through ERP Co partners, which could be platinum partners that only work for ERP Co and build their services around ERP Co products, or gold partners that mainly work with ERP Co but also engage with other businesses, or smaller partners and resellers that represent ERP Co or their products in micro markets and local markets around the country.' | Page 5: 'up to 50% of the initial ERP Co license fees do go to VAR' | Page 7, Section 6.1: 'the platinum partners collaborate with ERP Co to achieve "synergistic integration," in which new products and services are developed by the partners based on the ERP Co system, and both sides reinforce each other and achieve value co-creation, whereas gold partners and smaller partners might mainly engage in "addition" or "exchange" type of collaboration with ERP Co' | Page 7, Section 6.1: 'This is also true for the main vendor â€“ Microsoft - who sells competing software on global scale.' | Page 5: 'their major providers include ERP Co IT (a company owned by ERP Co) and Microsoft.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?

extracted_value.role: Strategic asset and knowledge workers who build the software offering
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Managed through motivation, empowerment, and trust rather than command and control; require tools, hardware, and organizational structures to write great software
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Not specified

extracted_value.role: End users who request features and consume the software/service
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Request features; provide requirements; work closely with developers in agile processes; frequent delivery recipients
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Create network effects by increasing offering value with more users

extracted_value.role: Other businesses that depend on the platform and grow together with it
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Depend on the platform/ecosystem for their business growth
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Grow together in ecosystem

extracted_value.role: Contributors for crowdsourced software development and support
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Provide crowdsourced development and support; require building and maintaining a live community
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Not specified

extracted_value.role: External parties that may handle software construction
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Potential outsourcing relationship for software construction, though article questions what value company offers if construction is outsourced
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Not specified

extracted_value.role: Competing software businesses in the market
extracted_value.interaction_with_offering_company: Competitors that become easier to build competing products each year; can also use same open source components
extracted_value.interaction_with_other_actors: Compete for customers and talent

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'offering a platform or an ecosystem in which your business can grow together with others that depend on yours' | Page 2: 'Software construction might appear easy to outsource, but then what value are you offering?' | Page 2: 'You can even crowdsource software development and support, but building and maintaining a live volunteer community isn't for the fainthearted.' | Page 2: 'given the big productivity differences among developers, your engineers will likely be a strategic asset' | Page 2: 'An important guide is obviously the set of features your existing or potential customers have requested.' | Page 3: 'Here, you must bring the customer close to the developers, ensure the software's frequent delivery' | Page 4: 'As clever specialized knowledge workers, developers can't be effectively managed through command and control. The tools you'll use are motivation, empowerment, and trust.'
